content.raw:
Can this same functionality be contained within the `SimulationRunner` code? This would reduce the amount of code, and the GuiBroadcaster plugin XML tag in world files.

It looks like a System is overkill of this functionality, and the gui broadcast service is so fundamental that it should always be present and can live outside of a System.
content.html:
Can this same functionality be contained within the SimulationRunner code? This would reduce the amount of code, and the GuiBroadcaster plugin XML tag in world files.

It looks like a System is overkill of this functionality, and the gui broadcast service is so fundamental that it should always be present and can live outside of a System.

content.raw:
I considered this, I don't have strong feelings either way, but some of the pros of using a system which I could think of were:

* It can be easily "turned off" by removing the tags from the world file, so users running headless don't have the extra service
* In the future, we could support systems modifying the GUI layout by modifying the GUI component (but I don't think this will be a common use case)
content.html:
I considered this, I don't have strong feelings either way, but some of the pros of using a system which I could think of were:

  • It can be easily "turned off" by removing the tags from the world file, so users running headless don't have the extra service
  • In the future, we could support systems modifying the GUI layout by modifying the GUI component (but I don't think this will be a common use case)

content.raw:
An extra service probably doesn't add a lot of overhead, @caguero maybe you can check that statement.

This feels like a situation where we are adding a feature (enable or disable gui service), which might be useful to a small set of people but most people will want it always on. I can imagine a more likely scenario where users forget to include this System and then the GUI doesn't work. Or, if you want to run headless, but want to test with the GUI then you'll need two separate world files. Similarly, sharing world files would be more difficult. I'm in favor of making this a built in feature, and reduce the number of options a user has to deal with.
content.html:
An extra service probably doesn't add a lot of overhead, @caguero maybe you can check that statement.

This feels like a situation where we are adding a feature (enable or disable gui service), which might be useful to a small set of people but most people will want it always on. I can imagine a more likely scenario where users forget to include this System and then the GUI doesn't work. Or, if you want to run headless, but want to test with the GUI then you'll need two separate world files. Similarly, sharing world files would be more difficult. I'm in favor of making this a built in feature, and reduce the number of options a user has to deal with.

content.raw:
> An extra service probably doesn't add a lot of overhead

Yup, that's most likely true

> but most people will want it always on

I agree lots of people will want it on, but we shouldn't forget all the Gazebo instances being launched for CI and testing, which are usually headless.

> I can imagine a more likely scenario where users forget to include this System and then the GUI doesn't work

Agreed that users may forget it, but that's also true for the `SceneBroadcaster`, which is needed by the GUI (for now, we may change that once we have distributed systems).

As for the GUI not working, that's not really true, users could always launch an empty `ign gui` window and insert plugins as needed. Granted, currently they're not configurable on insertion, but this will hopefully be tackled soon.

> if you want to run headless, but want to test with the GUI then you'll need two separate world files

As described above, not necessarily 2 world files, but yes, ign-gui still lacks a couple of features to make that convenient.

> reduce the number of options a user has to deal with

I agree with that, but I don't think removing flexibility is the solution. Instead, I think we should figure out how to give the users good default behaviour.

---

In any case, I'm not opposed to moving this out of a system. I'll work on that soon.
content.html:
An extra service probably doesn't add a lot of overhead

Yup, that's most likely true

but most people will want it always on

I agree lots of people will want it on, but we shouldn't forget all the Gazebo instances being launched for CI and testing, which are usually headless.

I can imagine a more likely scenario where users forget to include this System and then the GUI doesn't work

Agreed that users may forget it, but that's also true for the SceneBroadcaster, which is needed by the GUI (for now, we may change that once we have distributed systems).

As for the GUI not working, that's not really true, users could always launch an empty ign gui window and insert plugins as needed. Granted, currently they're not configurable on insertion, but this will hopefully be tackled soon.

if you want to run headless, but want to test with the GUI then you'll need two separate world files

As described above, not necessarily 2 world files, but yes, ign-gui still lacks a couple of features to make that convenient.

reduce the number of options a user has to deal with

I agree with that, but I don't think removing flexibility is the solution. Instead, I think we should figure out how to give the users good default behaviour.

In any case, I'm not opposed to moving this out of a system. I'll work on that soon.

content.raw:
Sounds good to me.

I want to expand on flexibility vs default behavior. We have tended to favor flexibility over good defaults and this leads to extra code and options which degrade the value of our libraries and programs. I want to flip this tendency so that we prefer sacrificing flexibility in deference to good default behavior. When possible, we can make 2nd-tier features available, but these features should be protected. For example, a person that *doesn't* want the gui broadcaster should be required to add something to the world file or use a command line option. If a 2nd-tier feature cannot be protected, then we should not add it. Determination of a 2nd-tier feature is up to us, and is fuzzy.
content.html:
Sounds good to me.

I want to expand on flexibility vs default behavior. We have tended to favor flexibility over good defaults and this leads to extra code and options which degrade the value of our libraries and programs. I want to flip this tendency so that we prefer sacrificing flexibility in deference to good default behavior. When possible, we can make 2nd-tier features available, but these features should be protected. For example, a person that doesn't want the gui broadcaster should be required to add something to the world file or use a command line option. If a 2nd-tier feature cannot be protected, then we should not add it. Determination of a 2nd-tier feature is up to us, and is fuzzy.

content.raw: Cool, I think we're on the same page. In my opinion, Gazebo <= 9 has very little flexibility, users get all features by default, and most features would require going into the source code to be disabled. On ign-gazebo however, I think we're going in a good direction by offering the option to disable features in a granular way. We do have some degree of features being enabled by default (i.e. no world file), but that needs to be improved to work with custom world files.
content.html: Cool, I think we're on the same page. In my opinion, Gazebo <= 9 has very little flexibility, users get all features by default, and most features would require going into the source code to be disabled. On ign-gazebo however, I think we're going in a good direction by offering the option to disable features in a granular way. We do have some degree of features being enabled by default (i.e. no world file), but that needs to be improved to work with custom world files.

content.raw: This discussion goes beyond this small detail, but I confirm that an extra service doesn’t add a lot of overhead.
content.html: This discussion goes beyond this small detail, but I confirm that an extra service doesn’t add a lot of overhead.
